entry.title: è«‹å•å‘¢æ¢4K gaming List æœ‰å†‡å•é¡Œ?
entry.content:
Published on: 2025-08-19T19:18:00+0800


Building a 4K gaming PC in 2025 requires high-end components to achieve smooth performance at ultra-high resolutions. Below is a recommended parts list optimized for 4K gaming, balancing performance, value, and availability based on current market trends. This build targets ~$2,000â€“$2,500, suitable for 4K gaming at high settings with 60+ FPS in most AAA titles, leveraging insights from recent sources. Prices are approximate and may vary by region and retailer.
4K Gaming PC Build List (August 2025)
CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 9800X3D 4.7 GHz 8-Core Processor
  • Price: ~$480
  • Why: The Ryzen 7 9800X3D is the best gaming CPU on the market, with enhanced 3D V-Cache technology for superior gaming performance, outperforming Intelâ€™s latest processors in gaming tasks. Its 8 cores and 16 threads handle modern games and multitasking efficiently.
CPU Cooler: Thermalright Phantom Spirit 120 SE ARGB 66.17 CFM
  • Price: ~$40
  • Why: A high-performance air cooler thatâ€™s cost-effective and sufficient for the Ryzen 7 9800X3D, avoiding the need for an AIO liquid cooler unless overclocking.
Motherboard: MSI MAG B650 TOMAHAWK WIFI ATX AM5
  • Price: ~$190
  • Why: A reliable AM5 motherboard with robust VRM, WiFi 6, and support for DDR5 and PCIe 4.0/5.0, ensuring compatibility with the Ryzen 7 9800X3D and future upgrades.
Memory (RAM): TEAMGROUP T-Force Vulcan 32 GB (2 x 16 GB) DDR5-6000 CL30
  • Price: ~$100
  • Why: 32GB of DDR5-6000 provides ample memory for 4K gaming and multitasking. The 6000 MHz speed with low CL30 latency is ideal for AMDâ€™s AM5 platform. Enable EXPO in BIOS for optimal performance.
Storage: Western Digital WD_Black SN850X 2 TB M.2-2280 PCIe 4.0 NVMe SSD
  • Price: ~$150
  • Why: A 2TB PCIe 4.0 SSD offers fast load times and ample storage for large 4K game files. The SN850X is known for excellent 4K read performance, critical for gaming.
Video Card (GPU): Nvidia GeForce RTX 5070 Ti 16GB
  • Price: ~$900
  • Why: The RTX 5070 Ti delivers excellent 4K performance, averaging 61.2 FPS at 4K ultra settings in tests, and supports DLSS 4 for AI-enhanced frame rates. Itâ€™s a strong value compared to the pricier RTX 5090 ($2,919) or RTX 5080.
Alternative GPU: AMD Radeon RX 9070 XT 16GB
  • Price: ~$600
  • Why: A budget-friendly option for 4K gaming, offering 60+ FPS at 4K with FSR 4 upscaling. Itâ€™s less effective for ray tracing compared to the RTX 5070 Ti but provides great value.
Case: Lian Li LANCOOL 216 ATX Mid Tower
  • Price: ~$100
  • Why: Offers excellent airflow, a roomy interior for large GPUs, and a sleek design with good cable management. Supports high-end components and future upgrades.
Power Supply (PSU): Corsair RM850x (2024) 850W 80+ Gold Fully Modular ATX
  • Price: ~$140
  • Why: An 850W PSU provides ample power for the RTX 5070 Ti or RX 9070 XT, with 80+ Gold efficiency and full modularity for clean builds. Offers headroom for future upgrades.
Operating System: Windows 11 Home
  • Price: ~$120
  • Why: Windows 11 supports the latest gaming features like DirectStorage and is compatible with modern hardware.
Total Estimated Cost: ~$2,220 (with RTX 5070 Ti) or ~$1,920 (with RX 9070 XT)
Additional Recommendations
  • Monitor: A 4K monitor with at least 60Hz refresh rate and HDMI 2.0/DisplayPort 1.2 (preferably 2.1) is essential. Look for G-Sync (Nvidia) or FreeSync (AMD) support for smoother gameplay. Budget options start at ~$350.
  • Peripherals: Pair with a high-quality gaming keyboard, mouse, and headset for a complete setup. Consider brands like SteelSeries for immersive audio.
Notes
  • Performance: This build achieves 60+ FPS at 4K ultra settings in most AAA games, with the RTX 5070 Ti offering better ray tracing and DLSS 4 support. The RX 9070 XT is ideal for budget-conscious builds but may require turning off ray tracing for demanding titles.
  • Overclocking: Optional for extra performance. Enable EXPO for RAM and consider GPU overclocking with tools like MSI Afterburner.
  • Build Guide: If new to PC building, follow a step-by-step guide (e.g., Paulâ€™s Hardware on YouTube) and use a screwdriver for assembly.
  • Availability: GPU prices may be above MSRP due to demand. Check retailers like Newegg, Amazon, or Micro Center for stock.
  • Prebuilt Option: If building isnâ€™t preferred, consider prebuilt systems from Starforge Systems, CLX Gaming, or Gladiator PC, starting at ~$1,880 for 4K-ready configs.
For detailed component compatibility, use PCPartPicker. If your budget is tighter or you prefer a prebuilt system, let me know, and I can adjust the recommendations!
